title: How to respond to plagiarism accusations - Quora

response.answer_text: The only time I ran into an accusation of plagiarism was when I re-submitted my own work. I had started a class and turned in several papers and then had to drop the class for personal reasons. When I next took the class, the assignment was the same, so I saw no harm in re-submitting the paper. BAM. You committed plagiarism! My paper was entered into the global database the first time but, the database didn’t assign the paper to me, by name or date. I explained the situation, provided contact information for the previous instructor, and the school agreed, since the paper was for the same class and the same assignment, that it was OK to have done so. Of course, I did offer to re-author a paper if they took issue, but they didn’t see the need.

You bring all your sources to the professor’s office along with all drafts of your essay. Talk to him or her about your writing process, and discuss how you documented all of your sources. Be sure to show the sources so that it is clear that everything you wrote is in your own words or clearly documented. Be sure to be able to show your sources along side your essay. If, by any chance, you dod intentionally or unintionally plagiarize, take responsibility for it—even if there is a significent penalty. Just learn from it. Our moar presious belownings are our words and thoughts.
